Welcome to the BBC's World of Business podcast. I'm Caroline Bailey.

river from where I'm standing are the headquarters of Rosneft, Russia's biggest oil company, which is state-controlled.
The links between the two are quite inextricable.
I'm Caroline Bailey, and in this episode of Global Business
on the BBC World Service, I'm asking why the Russian economy needs to diversify
and whether it can succeed in doing so.

after an accident 10 years ago.
The exoskeleton he's demonstrating is made by ExoAtlut,
one of Russia's new breed of tech companies,
a sector which the government hopes will help move the economy away from its reliance on energy.
Can I just ask you, Dennis, how does it feel?
It's amazing.
We'll come back to Dennis a bit later.
But first, let's establish just how significant oil is to Russia.
We in Russia literally do not have presidents being people. It's oil being the president of
Russia. Said with feeling by Andrei Movchan, an independent economist at the Moscow
Carnegie Center, which is part of an international think tank. His aim, he tells me, is...

But if he believes oil is the real power behind Russia,
how does it all add up within the economy?
Russia is a country rich in natural resources,
with an abundance of hydrocarbons such as oil, gas and coal.
Well, Russian economy is rather simple.
The GDP construction starts with about 30% of the GDP being brought by the natural resources.
You should add 15% of the GDP made by energy production and distribution.
Would you say it still is very much an energy-based economy?
Yes, if you look at the ruble dollar rate, for example,
the ruble dollar rate is defined by just one perimeter of the price of oil.
Nothing else is important in terms of price of the collateral of the economy.
He says that 80% of Russia's exports are directly related to hydrocarbons,
which doesn't leave much room for anything else.
There are other countries such as Norway that rely on energy.
They don't really seem to have diversified their economies.
Do you think it matters?
Yes and now.
Norway has about five times more oil per capita than Russia.
So it's easy to be Norway or United Arabic Emirates, for example.
We have as much oil per capita as Kazakhstan or Venezuela or Iran. It's very hard
